brief_description: This is a non randomized observational study to assess the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a panel of noninvasive monitoring tests as correlates with acute rejection, graft loss, deterioration of renal function, and degree of graft fibrosis in renal allograft recipients receiving commonly used immunosuppressive regimens.
description: This is a non randomized observational study to assess the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a panel of noninvasive monitoring tests as correlates with acute rejection, graft loss, deterioration of renal function, and degree of graft fibrosis in renal allograft recipients receiving commonly used immunosuppressive regimens.
endpoints: The primary endpoint is a composite endpoint of death-censored graft failure, clinically evident acute rejection, or strictly defined abnormalities of renal histology. The secondary endpoint is the change in GFR between 6 and 24 months post transplantation. We propose to correlate non invasive test results during the initial 6 months post transplant with renal function and biopsy results obtained at those two time points.
hypothesis: Comprehensive noninvasive monitoring approaches will detect subclinical graft injury and thereby have a strong association with short- and long-term outcome in renal allograft recipients and providing an additional assessment of risk.
objectives: The objective of this observational study is to determine whether any single test, or a combination of tests, obtained during the first 6 months after transplantation in adults is associated with the absence of the composite endpoint at 6 months (i.e., incidence of clinically evident acute rejection, subclinical injury, graft loss, death) identifying low risk patients. Each of the proposed noninvasive monitoring test results will be assessed individually and jointly for their discriminatory ability for outcomes.
